The end date of the last government shutdown, marking the conclusion of the 35-day event that was the longest in nearly 50 years.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The duration of the 35-day shutdown in 2018–2019, the longest in history, which cost the U.S. an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP.
The current full government shutdown, which began with the failure to pass any of the 12 appropriations bills, resulting in all federal operations being halted.

keyTakeAways: The last government shutdown, from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019, lasted 35 days and was the longest in U.S. history.
The shutdown cost the U.S. economy an estimated $3 billion in lost GDP, according to the Congressional Budget Office.
During the 2018–2019 shutdown, about 800,000 federal workers were affected, with approximately 300,000 furloughed and 500,000 exempt from pay but required to report to work.
The current government shutdown (as of October 2025) is a full shutdown, meaning no federal agencies are operating, unlike the partial shutdown in 2018–2019.
The current Congress has not passed any of the 12 appropriations bills needed to fund the U.S. government.
The political stalemate is attributed to a narrow Republican majority in the House, led by Speaker Mike Johnson, and the lack of 60 votes in the Senate to overcome a filibuster.
Government shutdowns have become less common since 1990, but increasing partisanship in Washington has made it harder to reach consensus on funding.
The first federal government shutdown occurred in 1976, and since then, U.S. agencies have been instructed to cease operations during funding lapses.

summaryOfNewsArticle: The article reports on the current U.S. government shutdown, which is a full shutdown due to the failure to pass any of the 12 required appropriations bills. It notes that this marks a continuation of political stalemate, with the current Congress unable to reach agreement despite narrow majorities and Senate filibuster rules. It references the longest shutdown in history—35 days from December 22, 2018, to January 25, 2019—which cost the economy an estimated $3 billion and affected around 800,000 federal workers, with 300,000 furloughed. Unlike the partial 2018 shutdown, the current shutdown affects all federal operations. The article attributes the ongoing impasse to partisan gridlock, particularly the narrow House majority under Speaker Mike Johnson and the Senate’s lack of a quorum to break a filibuster, highlighting both the political and economic consequences of such events.
